item.title: Russia’s Retreat in Ukraine Pokes Holes in Putin’s Projection of Force
item.description: Russia’s military setbacks may be weakening President Vladimir V. Putin’s reputation at home as a savvy geopolitical strategist.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Juan Barreto/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The scene in the Kharkiv region this weekend after Russian forces retreated.

item.title: U.N. Agency, Ukraine and Russia in Talks to End Fighting at Nuclear Plant
item.description: The nuclear complex in southern Ukraine has been imperiled by frequent shelling, raising fears of a nuclear catastrophe.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Christian Bruna/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Rafael Mariano Gross of the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna on Monday. He said Russia and Ukraine “were engaging with us” over talks to end fighting at the nuclear plant.

item.title: How Poverty Programs Aided Children From One Generation to the Next
item.description: For families in West Virginia, which has had especially sharp drops in child poverty over the past three decades, the shift has played out in ways not fully captured by statistics.
item.dc:creator: Jason DeParle and Maddie McGarvey
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Jackson family benefits from a safety net that has expanded significantly over the last generation.

item.title: Expanded Safety Net Drives Sharp Drop in Child Poverty
item.description: With little public notice and accelerating speed, child poverty fell by 59 percent from 1993 to 2019, according to a comprehensive new analysis that shows the critical role of increased government aid.
item.dc:creator: Jason DeParle and Maddie McGarvey

item.title: A Local Prosecutor Takes on Trump and Crime in Atlanta
item.description: Fani T. Willis has emerged as one of the most consequential legal threats to Donald Trump while presiding over the justice system in Georgia’s most populous county.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fani T. Willis, the Fulton County district attorney, in Atlanta last month.

item.title: Trump Asks Judge to Keep Blocking F.B.I. From Working With Seized Classified Files
item.description: It was the latest salvo in a court fight over a special master, which has stalled an investigation into the former president’s hoarding of government documents.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump has succeeded for now in using a procedural sideshow to divert and stall the criminal investigation into his hoarding of sensitive government documents.

item.title: The Horse Whisperer and Queen Elizabeth
item.description: A renowned American horse trainer described his three-decade-long friendship with Queen Elizabeth II, and the time she called him, unexpectedly, at 2:30 a.m.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
The Man Who Listens to Horses (Book)
item.media:credit: David Butow for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Roberts and a photo of the queen. “When the queen was with horses, she was a horse person,” he said.

item.title: As Harvard Makes Amends for Its Ties to Slavery, Descendants Ask, What Is Owed?
item.description: A woman who lived in the shadows of Harvard discovers, at 80, that her enslaved ancestors had links to the university.
item.media:credit: Vanessa Leroy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roberta Wolff-Platt standing outside of the Longfellow House in Cambridge, Mass., the home where her ancestor Darby Vassall was enslaved.

item.title: Democrats’ Midterm Dilemma: How to Back Biden, Yet Shun Him, Too
item.description: Democratic candidates have been trying to signal their independence from the White House, while not distancing themselves from his base or his agenda.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden takes the stage at the summer gathering of the Democratic National Committee on Sept. 8. The last time a party maintained control of Congress with an unpopular president was in 1978.

item.title: In New Hampshire, an Intraparty G.O.P. Fight for the Senate Intensifies
item.description: On the eve of the state’s primary on Tuesday, mainstream Republicans have been vying to stop an election denier running for Senate.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel and Michael C. Bender
item.media:credit: John Tully for The New York Times
item.media:description: Don Bolduc, center, during a campaign appearance at the American Legion in Laconia, N.H., on Saturday.

item.title: Yes, the Polling Warning Signs Are Flashing Again
item.description: Democrats are polling well in exactly the places where surveys missed most in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Dustin Franz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The midterms are on Nov. 8, less than two months away.

item.title: Introducing ‘The Tilt,’ a Newsletter About Elections and Polling
item.description: Political analysis in your inbox, twice a week or more, for Times subscribers.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Gene J. Puskar/Associated Press

item.title: Who Are America’s Missing Workers?
item.description: The labor market appears hot, but the share of people who are either working or actively looking for a job still hasn’t quite recovered.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.media:credit: Al J. Thompson for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I could jump back in, but then I got used to being retired,” said Thomas Strait, who chose early retirement at the beginning of the pandemic.

item.title: NY State Vote Could Raise Pressure on Officials Over Hasidic Schools
item.description: Amid calls for intervention, the state Board of Regents is set to vote this week on new rules for holding private schools to minimum academic standards.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro and Brian M. Rosenthal
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boys who attend private Hasidic religious schools are suffering from levels of educational deprivation that occur nowhere else in New York, a Times investigation found.

item.title: In Hasidic Enclaves, Failing Yeshivas Flush With Public Money
item.description: New York’s Hasidic Jewish religious schools have benefited from $1 billion in government funding in the last four years but are unaccountable to outside oversight.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro, Brian M. Rosenthal and Jonah Markowitz
item.media:credit: Jonah Markowitz for The New York Times

item.title: Must We Discuss the Queen and the Donald in the Same Breath?
item.description: For one thing, the job of king is already taken.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Hillbilly Elegy: A Memoir of a Family and Culture in Crisis (Book)
item.media:credit: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images

item.title: Mark Finchem Says Biden Didn’t Win in 2020, and He Has Big Plans for Elections in Arizona
item.description: What happens if you follow the logic of the Republican nominee for Arizona secretary of state?
item.dc:creator: Katherine Miller
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Finchem.

item.title: The Wives of Republican Candidates Are Getting Personal
item.description: The Republican Party is under particular pressure to slap a friendly face on its nominees, with a special focus on wooing women.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle
item.media:credit: Illustration by Leslie dela Vega/The New York Times, photographs by clockwise from top: Martha Asencio-Rhine/Tampa Bay Times, via Associated Press; John Lamparski/Getty Images; Tom R. Smedes/Associated Press; Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times; Gaelen Morse/Reuters

item.title: The Radical Constitutional Change Britain Needs
item.description: Might the Queen’s death lead to unstoppable pressure for radical constitutional change, even a new British constitution?
item.dc:creator: Linda Colley
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Dan Kitwood/Getty Images

item.title: Democrats’ Black Male Voter Problem
item.description: Stacey Abrams is concerned about Black male turnout in her race for governor in Georgia. She’s not the only Democrat who should be worried.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times

item.title: The Killing of Eliza Fletcher Is a Tragedy, Not a Morality Play
item.description: She didn’t live and die to illustrate any point or serve a political agenda.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl
item.media:credit: Mark Weber/Daily Memphian, via Associated Press

item.title: All Biden Has to Do Now Is Change the Way We Live
item.description: The president’s legacy — and our climate future — will turn on what actually gets built, and how fast.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 2022 Ford F-150 Lightning Electric truck in production at the Dearborn Truck Plant in Michigan.

item.title: How to Argue Well
item.description: A former debating champion offers advice for our polarized moment.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul
item.category: Good Arguments: How Debate Teaches Us to Listen and Be Heard (Book)
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; image by rasslava via Getty Images

item.title: Are the Polls Wrong Again?
item.description: Are Democrats again about to be disappointed by overly optimistic polling?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: A polling station in Miami Beach, Fla.

item.title: Serena Williams’s Final Run
item.description: Discussing the legacy of a sporting great whose remarkable career had a deep impact not only on tennis but also on American society at large.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Stella Tan, Sydney Harper, Rachelle Bonja, Diana Nguyen, Rachel Quester, Michael Simon Johnson, Luke Vander Ploeg, Mooj Zadie, John Ketchum, Mike Benoist, Marc Georges, Dan Powell, Chelsea Daniel, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Serena Williams serving at the U.S. Open in 2019. Although she didn’t win this year’s tournament, she didn’t exactly lose, either.

item.title: In Premier League, Crisis Is a Constant
item.description: Change at Chelsea. A loss at Liverpool. Chaos is part and parcel of the Premier League story line. But it doesn’t have to be that way.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:credit: Carl Recine/Pool Via Reuters
item.media:description: Thomas Tuchel, before the fall.

item.title: Why the U.S. Is Being Compared to Hungary and Turkey
item.description: A conversation with Max Fisher, who covers the decline of democracy around the world.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell and Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump, like other leaders around the world who have attacked democratic institutions, has appealed to supporters by promising to defeat internal threats to the country.

item.title: Mother Questioned Following Deaths of 3 Children Found on Brooklyn Shore
item.description: The children were found unconscious on Coney Island Beach after an emergency call early Monday morning. Their mother was discovered nearby, barefoot and “soaking wet,” the police said.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police on the boardwalk Monday.

item.title: Bronxites Fear More Traffic In Congestion Pricing Plan
item.description: New York City’s congestion pricing program could cut traffic in the busy commercial district but push more vehicles into vulnerable areas.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ley
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Jennie Jerome Playground overlooking the Cross Bronx Expressway. Traffic in the corridor has long been detrimental to the health of area residents and linked to high rates of asthma.

item.title: Carlos Alcaraz Wins US Open Men’s Singles Title, and Becomes No. 1
item.description: Alcaraz, the 19-year-old Spanish sensation, beat Casper Ruud of Norway in four sets to capture his first Grand Slam championship and take the top spot in the ATP world rankings.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Carlos Alcaraz, 19, became the youngest man to win a Grand Slam title since Rafael Nadal in 2005.

item.title: Can you get reinfected with monkeypox?
item.description: Experts weigh in on how long immunity lasts after an infection — or vaccination.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images

item.title: Why Can’t I Stand the Sound of Chewing? Misophonia, Explained
item.description: Misophonia, a little-known syndrome, is characterized by strong negative emotional reactions to certain sounds or visual cues.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Guillem Casasús

item.title: We Want to Hear About Your Experience With Egg Freezing
item.description: The Times is looking for stories from readers.
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times

item.title: The Power of a Casual Check-in Text
item.description: New research says most of us underestimate the power of the casual check-in.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.category: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
item.media:credit: Moritz Wienert

item.title: How Family and Friends Helped Get Me Through the Pandemic
item.description: As Covid raged, many Americans hunkered down with family members and relied on friends — and some came away with deepened relationships. Here are a few of their stories.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Needelman
item.media:credit: Cig Harvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rita and Jon Ellis at Lermond Pond in Maine. Mr. Ellis credits his wife for his recovery from pancreatic cancer. They are two of the many people who leaned on family and friends to help them through a difficult couple of years.
